respStmt.resp: Encoded in TEI P5 XML by
respStmt.name: Jordan Rosen-Kaplan

publicationStmt.publisher: TO BE DECIDED! SOMETHING ABOUT STANFORD

app.lem: La visión de Filiberto
app.rdg: Filbert's Vision

app.lem: ¶ vn omne bueno ermjtano que llamaron fyliberto era omne de buen lynage ca deçendia de lynage de rreys de françia ¶
app.rdg: A good man, a hermit that they called Filbert, was a man of respectable lineage; indeed, he was a descendant of the kings of France.

app.lem: et consyderando las cosas desta vida ser conrronpibres ¶ et menos preçiando las propuso de serujr adios λ
app.rdg: Considering worldly things to be a source of corruption, and not valuing them, he dedicated himself to the service of God.

app.lem: perseuerando enel serujçio de dios conpuso este lybro enel qual puso λ escriujo muy santas palabras de vna ujsion que vio λ ¶ asy açaiçio vysion filoberto
app.rdg: In observance of his service to God, he composed this book in which he laid down and wrote very holy words of a vision that he saw, thus occurred Filbert’s vision:

app.lem: que seyendo tienpo de ynbierno estando en vna ermjta enel mayor sylençio dela noche ¶ et queriendo me partyr de la luenga vegilya que auja contynuado en mjs oraçiones fue arrebatado mj entendimjento de vn suenno muy sotil semejante a suenno λ a vision espiritual
app.rdg: Being that it was winter and standing in a shrine in the greatest silence of the night, and wishing to conclude my long vigil of prayer, my sensibilities were snatched away by a very subtle dream, a kind of spiritual vision.

app.lem: ¶ et aparesçio vn cuerpo de omne syn espiritu que paresçia que era ya partido del anjma λ
app.rdg: The body of a man appeared, a spiritless body that seemed to be separated from its soul.

app.lem: yo catando lo con espanto vyno vna anjma que auja salydo nueua mente del dicho cuerpo aque yo estaua catando λ començe allorar muy triste mente dando grandes alaridos mal trayendo agraujada
app.rdg: While I was observing this with terror, a spirit appeared that had just left from this same body, and it started to cry very sadly and screamed at its body with much contempt.

app.lem: mente asu cuerpo que estaua presente λ asentose çerca del llorando λ gjmjendo con grandes sospiros doliendo se mucho delos exçesos λ pecados que auja fechos la su malyçiosa carne ¶ et cuerpo que ante sy veya λ mal dezyendo al cuerpo començo arrazonarse lo que se sygue
app.rdg: And it sat close to it crying and sighing deep breaths in great pain from the excesses and sins that its malicious corpse had committed, and berating its body, it began to reason with itself in the following manner:

app.lem: ¶ o carne mesquina dime quien es el que te asy ha quebrantado λ dyrybado aty que tan marabjllo[^sa]mente te auja en rrequiçido estos tienpos pasados en aquel mundo do somos partidos
app.rdg: “O miserable corpse, tell me, who is it that has broken you and torn you down since you have so marvelously enriched yourself from times past in that world from which we have departed.

app.lem: tu bien viste este otro dia enel que ¶ tenjas grand poder sobre todo el mundo ¶et te tenjan y tan grand mjedo
app.rdg: You certainly saw this in times past when you had great power over the whole world and you paralyzed others with fear.

app.lem: et eres otrosy de todas las prouençias ¶et las tierras pues que es dela conpanna que te serujan rricos omnes λ muchos fijos dalgo λ grandes escuderos λ de grand oficina λ muy loçanos λ muy brauos que yuan en pos de ty λ
app.rdg: And you were, furthermore, served in all lands and provinces by rich men, and many nobles, and important squires of high office, valiant and brave, that followed you around.

app.lem: tu delante dellos fazyendo grandes jestos λ contenientes carne mesquina ya este tu rrastro λ esta tu locura que leuauas en posty λ tu mas pyntado que pendola de pauon ya agora es cortada para sienpre
app.rdg: And you, in front of all of them, making such extravagant gestures, now look at you. Miserable corpse, this madness that you wore as gaudy as peacock pendant, now all of it is gone forever.

app.lem: ya non estas enlas torres njn en los palaçios muy espaçiosos λ de grand largura que tu aujas fechos delos alcaçeres do tu aujas grandes deleytes mas yazes agora enese ataud pequenno λ enesa fuesa de pequenna quantydat
app.rdg: Now you do not dwell in towers, or in the copious and spacious royal palaces that you so delighted in, but rather, you lie in this small coffin, in this tiny grave.

app.lem: pues dime que te aprouechan agora tus moradas λ tus grandes onrras λ tan grandes palaçios λ tan rricos commo aujas fechos pues esta casa lobrega ¶ et monjmento enque ya ses tyene largura ¶ et espaçio a malabes de siete pyes
app.rdg: Well now, tell me how you enjoy your great honors and riches inside of this gloomy house seven feet under?

app.lem: λ ya agora non judgaras njn condenaras A njnguno delos que solias falsa mente condenar quando pronunçiauas tus falsas sentençias
app.rdg: Now you cannot judge or condemn any of those who you falsely accused when you pronounced your false sentences.

app.lem: por las queles obras que tu feziste es nos dado amj λ aty sylla muy espantosa λ morada muy triste de dolor enel ynfierno para sienpre jamas
app.rdg: Because of the deeds you committed, now you and I will dwell in sadness and pain in hell forevermore.

app.lem: ¶ et yo mesquina triste λ tan apuesta λ tan lynpia fuy criada de mj sennor dios que me formo ala su semejança
app.rdg: And poor sad me, so clean and well disposed, I was brought into the world by my Lord God who made me in his likeness.

app.lem: ¶ et maguer que tu por el pecado que peco nuestro padre adan yo fuy en susiada del pecado original λ para ya avia seydo lauada por agua dela santa fuente del bautismo
app.rdg: Regardless of the fact that, for the original sin that our father Adam committed, I was stained by this original sin through you, I was cleansed of it by the holy water of baptism.

app.lem: ¶ et tu de cabo me acarreaste con tus falagosa errar contra mj sennor ihesu xpisto ¶et ser aborreçida dela su piadosa madre santa maria λ de toda la corte delos çielos λ piensa agora sy yo que tanto bien perdy sy puedo bien dezyr mjs llantos ay mesquina para que fuy naçida
app.rdg: And you afterward, drew my away with your defiance against my Lord Jesus Christ, being forsaken by his pious mother, the Holy Mary, and by all the courts of the heavens. And to think now of all the good that I had lost, if I can make my cries known, oh poor me, why was I born?

app.lem: ay quien nunca oujeste salido del vientre de mj madre do me cryo el mj sennor dios quien nunca fuese venjda a este mundo
app.rdg: Oh, that I had never left the womb of my mother where the Lord God created me, that I had never been brought into this world!

app.lem: sy quier por que non fuese enlas penas del ynfierno mas que estas penas ayamos tu λ yo non es syn
app.rdg: At least I would not have experienced the pain of hell if it weren’t for the deeds that you committed.

app.lem: rrazon ca mjentras que beujste nunca vna buena obra sola mente dexaste fazer mas syenpre cure con tu enganno me llegaste ala conpannia delos demonjos λ alas penas ynfernales enlas quales syenpre seremos
app.rdg: And for good reason, for while you drank you never did a single good deed, and your trickery has brought me into the company of demons, and in the infernal pain that I will never escape.

app.lem: en dolor λ en tristeza λ lloro λ llanto para syenpre jamas ay de mj que ya enella so λ sere ¶et por syenpre enlas penas estare
app.rdg: In pain, in sadness, I cry, weeping forever more, oh poor me, here I am and forever I will be.

app.lem: so muy triste por tan grandes commo su fijo la menor delas quales todas las lenguas del mundo non la poderian contar λ
app.rdg: I suffer such great sorrows for the sins you committed, the smallest of which all the languages of the world could not account for.

app.lem: mas mayor tresteza me quebranta ca ya nunca espero perdon del [^que] me formo
app.rdg: And worse, my heart is broken by the sadness that I will never be forgiven by he who made me.

app.lem: por que non me rrespondes
app.rdg: “Why aren’t you responding to me?

app.lem: dyme donde estan tus heredades que ayuntaste ¶ et los palaçios λ los grandes edefiçios que fundaste λ
app.rdg: Tell me where are the heredities that you accumulated, and the palaces, and the great buildings that you founded?

app.lem: dime cuerpo catyuo donde son las piedras preçiosas de grand valor λ los anjllos de oro que trayas do son los tesoros que allegaste do son las grandes alfajas λ rricas preseas que allegaste do son los vestidos de deujersas colores muy ofanos que cada dia rremudauas
app.rdg: Tell me, imprisoned corpse, where are the precious jewels of such great value, and the gold rings that you wore, where are the treasures you horded, and the great quantity of gems, and rich jewelry, and the colorful suits that you indulged in?

app.lem: do son los vasos de plata λ de oro muy rricos con que [^ca]da dia beujas
app.rdg: Where are the rich silver and gold goblets that you drank from each day?

app.lem: do son los confites λ espeçias de connortosos olores ¶ et los letuarios de maraujlloso sabores con que tomauas grandes deleytes en tus conbytes
app.rdg: Where are the confitures, and intoxicating smelling spices, and the marvelously flavored electuaries that you so delighted in at your feasts?

app.lem: no me pareçe que tyenes agora aues gruesas commo solias njn carnes saluajes λ salpresas commo solias njn tyenes otrosy carnes mortesynas de que te mucho pagauas njn vynos escojydos λ
app.rdg: I don’t think you will now have the fattened birds as you once did, or the preserved game meats as you did, nor will you have the tenderized meats that you paid so much for, nor the select wines.

app.lem: agora paramjentes sy te huele la cozyna tan bien commo solia que te ponian delante carnes de cisnes λ de ansares λ perdizes λ gallynas
app.rdg: Now in your confinement, can you smell the kitchen as well as you once did when they served you meats of swan, geese, quail, and chicken.

app.lem: bien creo que non te huele agora tan bien por que ya tu non comes njn puedes comer λ agora comen ay muchos busauos ¶ et lonbrizes λ muchas rretyllas λ muchas maneras de que esto es manjfiesto que la ley de dios dize que estos galardones han los pecadores que beujendo λ perseurando λ acabando su vida en pecado mortal ¶ et en los viçios λ plazeres del mundo
app.rdg: Surely, I don’t think you can smell well now because you no longer eat, or are able to eat, and now down there you eat many maggots and worms, many reptiles, and there are many ways in which this is manifest in the law of God that states that these are the rewards bestowed to sinners that have lived, maintained, and ended their lives in mortal sin, and in the vices and worldly pleasures.

app.lem: pagaste agora sy te paresçe desta casa enque estas que el su techo esta ençima del tu rrostro λ de tus narizes λ ya tyenes çiegos los ojos ¶ et ya calla la tu lengua λ ya tus membrios son quebrantados ¶ et desbueltos en tal manera que non podras jamas dellos aprouechar te
app.rdg: Now you paid for it, what do you think of the house you are in now with its ceiling right above your face, and nose, now that you are blind, and your tongue falls back into your mouth, and your limbs are broken and distorted in such a way that you will nevermore be able to enjoy yourself?”

app.lem: veyo otrosy mas que quantos algos λ quantas rriquezas λ heredades allegaste entan luengos tienpos beujste de lo ¶ et lo que oujste por engaño dello con manera de lo gro dello que rrobaste por fuerça dello que te dieron algunos mal de su grado todo esto te arrebato la muerte en vn punto
app.rdg: “Furthermore, it seems to me that whatever possessions, and riches, and bequests you received long ago were the result of trickery and forced robbery and your achievements were the misfortune of others to such a degree that death snatched you away in a single moment.

app.lem: non te çercan tus amjgos commo solian desque la muerte te çercan la flor de tu mançebia λ de tu fermosura ¶
app.rdg: Your friends no longer surround you as they once did since death encroached on the flower of your youth and beauty.

app.lem: et el amorío que tenjan contigo es perdido ya los llantos de tu muger ya son çesados λ ya olujdado te han ca las rriquesas que eredo de ty
app.rdg: And the lover you once had is lost, now the weeping of your mistress has ceased and she has already forgotten you other than the riches she inherited from you.

app.lem: ¶ et otrosy el dote que le tu mandaste gelo ha fecho olujdar non tenjas ya esperança enella njn en tus fijos njn en amjgos que tenjas ca poco se dan por ty que auran mas por aver plazer conlas heredades que rrobaste alos pobres ¶ Et conlas joyas λ los dineros quele dexaste que non de ty λ por lo qual [^l]loro yo agora
app.rdg: Furthermore, the dowry that you sent her has been forgotten and the faith that you had in her, and in your friends, was not merited for they did not care of you, only of the pleasure they would have from their inheritances that you robbed from the poor, and with the jewels and money that you left behind that weren’t yours and for which I now cry.”

app.lem: ¶ Et del dia del juyzio en adelante lloraremos entre amos para syenpre enel ynfierno
app.rdg: “And from the Day of Judgment onwards we’ll cry to each other forever in hell.

app.lem: carne mesquina piensas tu agora que njnguno destos tus heredades durase mucho la tristesa ¶ Et el llorar
app.rdg: Miserable corpse, do you think any of your heirs will cry and be sad for long?

app.lem: non lo cuydes ca sabe por çierto que njn tu muger njn tus fijos njn njngunos de tus amjgos non daran dos heredades njn vna delas mejores que les tu dexaste por que infermaste aty λ amj para que nos otros somos apartados de en medio dellos saliesemos del mal lugar ynfernal enque por ellos caymos λ
app.rdg: Assuredly you must know that they wouldn’t give anything of what you left them because you became sick, to me or to you so that we might leave from this hellish place where we ended up for their sake.

app.lem: delas penas ynfernales muy crueles en que auemos de padeçer o carne mesquina vees λ conosçes syn njnguna dubda que tan engannosa es aquella ujda λ tan bolliçiosa λ otrosy que tan suzya
app.rdg: And the cruel infernal pains that we must suffer, oh poor corpse, you see and know without a doubt that such is the delusion of that boisterous filthy lifestyle.

app.lem: ¶ Et quanto enpoçonnada del venjno del diablo non estas agora vestido de rricos pannos njn de grandes mantones que esa cobyjadura que tyenes avn malabes vale dos arbejas mas
app.rdg: Since the venom of the Devil has poisoned you, now you no longer wear such rich garments nor the great cloaks that even these covers, even of Arabic quality, are hardly worth two cents, but there is little hope of receiving eternal redemption or reward.

app.lem: espera vn poco que non as rreçebydo entera mente tu galardon non echaras ya alos pobres los trebutos njn los pechos que solias echar ¶ Et te solian pagar
app.rdg: But wait a little, for you have still not received your whole prize through the royal taxes taken from the bosoms of the poor, for they were the result of your robbery.

app.lem: ¶ Et por este rrobo que tu fazyas non cuydes que non as de sofrir mayor pena que esta enque te comen esos busanos
app.rdg: Don’t think that you won’t have to suffer more pains than this; where you are eaten by maggots.

app.lem: ca todos los escritos dela santa telogia dan testymonjo ¶ Et dizen que el cuerpo que ha de sofrir con el anjma gloria o pena del dia del juyzyo en adelante
app.rdg: Certainly all the scriptures of the holy theology testify to, and speak of the fact that the body suffers with the soul from the Day of Judgment onward.

app.lem: ¶ Et por que tu fuste rrobador delos pobres ¶ Et non eres padre dellos mas antes los en pobreçias por eso seras comjgo enel ynfierno del dia del juyzio en adelante a sofrir penas para sienpre jamas λ estare ay do te rroen esos busanos los costados
app.rdg: And because you stole from the poor and are not their father, but rather made them poorer, for this reason you will suffer alongside me in hell forever more, and you will remain there where the maggots gnaw at your ribs.

app.lem: ca non puedo aqui mas estar λ quiero me yr que en caso que pudiese estar non me podieras rresponder
app.rdg: Ah, I cannot stand being here and I wish that I could leave, and I’m certain that it is the case that you cannot respond to me.”

app.lem: bien so çierta P desque el anjma ouo dicho estas rrazones entrestyçiose el cuerpo vn poco ¶ Et paresçia que queria rrebeujr λ alço vn poco la cabeça λ oteo atodas partes λ maraujllandose mucho que cosa era la que tan mal le auja denostado ¶ Et vido esta su anjma çerca de sy enque non vio otro dando gemjdos ¶ Et sospyros ¶ Et començo de dezyr contra su anjma
app.rdg: Since the soul had dictated this rational, saddening the body a little, it appeared as though it wanted to come back to life, it lifted its head a little and looked around, and finding itself bewildered with what could have so badly chastised it, it saw its soul right next to it moaning and sighing, and began to rebuke its soul in the following way:

app.lem: pregunto te syeres tu aquel que agora fablaua comjgo
app.rdg: “I ask you now if you are the one who was speaking to me?

app.lem: çierto sy tu eres non es verdad todo lo que tu dixiste agora que en algo dello mentyste λ quiero telo prouar por claros λ
app.rdg: Certainly, if you are, none of what you have just said is true, somehow you have lied, and I want to make it clear to you.

app.lem: manjfiestos argumentos digo te que te conosçere que te fiz errar muchas de ueces
app.rdg: In expressing such an argument, you should know that you have made many errors.

app.lem: ¶ Et fuy ocasion aesas beses porque te yrases λ te rregrazes de buenas obras mas yo en quanto so carne ¶ Et fezyese errar aty en quanto anjma esto non es maraujlla
app.rdg: It was merely a coincidence that in these moments you should so anger yourself, and you comfort yourself with good deeds, but I being of the flesh must have made a mistake in choosing you as my soul.

app.lem: ¶ Et dizyr te he por que tu deues saber que el mundo λ el diablo feyeron aparçeria en vno
app.rdg: I must tell you that you should know that the world and the devil were created as one.

app.lem: λ posieron su fe ¶ Et postura que en quantos engannos podiesen en tantos troxiesen a las animas delos omnes
app.rdg: They put their faith in the multitude of ways that the spirits could deceive and trick the souls of men.

app.lem: λ esta postura fecha para que mayor afincamiento pudiese traer el anima del omne a perdiçion
app.rdg: This position was taken to best settle the way in which the soul could bring men into ruin.

app.lem: λ sacaron ala carne del omne por que fuese enesta aparçeria λ por que el diablo λ sus consejos malos
app.rdg: They separated the flesh from the man because he was formed through it by reason of the devil’s bad judgment.

app.lem: ¶ Et conel apetito dela carne otrosy conlas vanas glorias del mundo troxiese anima del omne al ynfierno
app.rdg: It is through the appetite of the flesh, where the vanities of the world are manifest, that the soul brings man down to hell.

app.lem: ¶ Et por sy yo fize errar aty fize rrazon
app.rdg: For this reason, I made a mistake with you.

app.lem: pues yo era enesta conpania λ la culpa deste error non fue mja mas fue tuya
app.rdg: I was logically in your company and the fault of this error was not mine but yours.

app.lem: ¶ Et prueuo lo asy ¶ Et fago vn argumento enesta manera delas rrazones que tu agora dixiste que dios te auja criado tan lynpia ¶Et tan nobre asu semejança
app.rdg: And I’ll prove it to you in the following way, and I’ll make an argument against your claim using the same logic and reasons that you have just said, that God had created you as pure, and so noble in his likeness.

app.lem: ¶ Et mager aujas sey do Amanzyllada del pecado origynal pero ya eres lauada ¶ Et lynpia por la fuente del santo bautysmo otrosy
app.rdg: Despite this I know where you were created, by original sin, but now you are cleansed and pure by the fountain of Holy Baptism.”

app.lem: pues dizes que te crio dios asu semejança pareçe pues te dio seso ¶ Et entendimjento ¶ Et rrazon que telo dio para con que me rregises ca non te lo dio para al saluo para que con el me rregises ¶ Et lo fesyeses serujçio λ a mj diome por tu syeruo para que ffezieses tu bondad
app.rdg: “Well, furthermore, you say that God created you in his likeness, and that it appears as though he also gave you wisdom and prudence with the understanding that he gave you these qualities in order to govern over me, and that you are in his service as a good gift to me.

app.lem: pues sy te dios crio para que toujeres sennorio sobre mj λ te dio rrazon ¶ Et seso con que me podieses castigar
app.rdg: If, indeed, God created you to govern over me, he gave you the right to judge and chastise me.

app.lem: ¶ Et tu en lugar de me acostrenir que fezyese tu voluntad
app.rdg: Instead of compelling me to make good choices, you allowed me to commit these actions.

app.lem: ¶ Et [^en] mjs obras me consentyste fazer lo que yo quise sy gese que la culpa es tuya
app.rdg: I, therefore, deem that you are guilty for my behavior, and that I am not to blame.”

app.lem: ¶ Et non mja prueuolo a sy por otro argumento
app.rdg: “And I’ll even prove it to you with another argument.

app.lem: todo aquel que es sennor λ por nesçesidat se abate de su obra λ se faze sieruo del que antes era su seruo deue ser condenado por culpador mas el su seruo deue quele estableçe por su sennor en vsar del sennorio enque lo pone el sennor que se somete A juridiçion
app.rdg: He who is a lord, and by necessity gives up his work, and makes himself the servant of the one who was formerly his servant, should be condemned as guilty.

app.lem: del que antes era seruo mas tu eras mj sennora para me mandar λ para me rregar λ para me costrenjr que feziese tu voluntad λ tu mandamjento
app.rdg: Once you were his servant, but you were my lady to govern and reign over me in order to compel me to act at your will and command.

app.lem: ¶ Et tu non quisiste vsar deste sennorio que dios te dio sobre mj λ fezyste amj tu sennora λ tu fueste mj sierua
app.rdg: And you did not want to use this power that God gave you over me and instead you made me your lady and you became my servant.

app.lem: pues segiste mj voluntad en todo lo que yo queria sabiendo λ entendiendo que te daua malos consejos sigese que pues la culpa es tuya λ non es mja ende
app.rdg: Well, you followed my lead in all that I wanted knowing and understanding that I had given you bad advice, so it should follow that you are guilty and I am not to blame.

app.lem: fize rrazon de vsar de sennorio pues me dieste lugar prueuase por el prouerbo que dize que todas las cosas del mundo cobdiçian ser mejoradas del estado enque estan ¶ Et por ende fize rrazon de vsar del sennorio pues tu melo diste para que del vsase
app.rdg: Finally, I had a right to uphold this position in your place and I’ll prove it to you with the proverb that says that: “all worldly things desire to be improved from the state they are in,” so, then, I had the right to uphold the authority that you have given me to use.

app.lem: ¶ Et que eras antes mj sennora prueuolo por que dize enel capytolo polytyçes que los omnes que han mjjores entendimjentos ¶Et son mas sabidores natural mente sennores λ rregidores delos otros mas
app.rdg: I will prove it to you as it says in the myth of Polynices, that men who of are of better judgment and naturally more wise, have the right to govern as lords over all the others.”

app.lem: aty dio el mj sennor el seso λ el saber λ el entender mas que non amj cayo solo por mj non se nada
app.rdg: “To you, my Lord gave wisdom and intelligence, but not to me, because I just alone, know nothing.

app.lem: ¶ Et tu syn mj sabes fabrar λ entender pues paresçe que naturalmente te crio dios por mj rregidora λ por mj sennora
app.rdg: And even without me you know how to speak and understand, well it seems that you were naturally formed by God to govern over me and as my lady.

app.lem: ¶ Et por esto paresçe que de antes era yo tu sierua mas fuy yo tu sennora λ tu mj sierua mas gelo tengo prouado
app.rdg: This is why it seems that once it was I that was your servant, but it was I who was your lady, and you my servant as I have now proved it.

app.lem: λ prueuo telo avn por el mjsmo letrado ay el que dize que faze mandados de otros son sieruos a estos
app.rdg: I will prove it to you even by the same lawyer because, he who says that he makes ordinances over others; they are the servants of who lack wisdom and good sense and have declared right to Polynices.

app.lem: dizen que son los que encareçen de sabidoria λ de seso onde este es su dicho enel primero policite ha do dize que los omnes que careçen de seso
app.rdg: As the saying goes, men who lack wisdom and understanding are naturally the submissive servants of other citizens, but you were the one who lacked reason.

app.lem: λ de entendimjento son naturalmente sieruos delos otros subditos ¶ Et su mjsos mas tu fueste tal que careçiste de rrazon prueuase pues non me quisiste rregir njn sopiste plueuase do dize λ quieres rregir todas las cosas vsaderra son λ somete ala rrazon λ ala sabidoria casy della vsares todo el mundo rregiras mas sy por sabidoria ¶ Et por rrazon non te regujeres non eres digno de vsar sennorio njn de aver sennorio sobre otros
app.rdg: Well, it’s proven that you did not want to govern me nor did you know how to prove where it’s stated, “You want to govern over all things, use your judgment, and submit to reason and wisdom because if you use reason, you will rule the whole world, but if you do not use wisdom and reason, you are not worthy.

app.lem: dela qual abtoridat paresçe pues que tu non me sopyste rregir
app.rdg: Well, it seems that you did not know how to govern me; you did not find in yourself wisdom enough to know how to govern me.

app.lem: non oujste enty sabiduria para me saber rregir
app.rdg: And in me you saw the wisdom that you could command.”

app.lem: ¶ Et en mj ovo sabidoria que te podiese mandar lo qual paresçe
app.rdg: And, in me, there was the acuity to know I could control you.

app.lem: ¶ Et pues fesyste todo lo que amj plugo sigese por la abtoridat te vid
app.rdg: You did everything that gave me pleasure.

app.lem: ¶ Et sigese que tu fueste mj sierua λ yo tu sennora
app.rdg: It, therefore, follows that you were my servant and I your lady.

app.lem: ¶ Et pues tu de sennora que eras te fesiste mj sierua
app.rdg: You as the lady that you were, you made yourself my servant.

app.lem: tuya es la culpa del danno λ del mal que te ha venjdo ¶ Et non es mja
app.rdg: All of this damage and the bad that has come with it is your fault; it’s not mine.”

app.lem: ca tu quando veyas que yo queria fazer algo que non conplia deujeras me diariamente castigar confanbre λ con sed ¶ Et con açotes
app.rdg: “Certainly, when you saw that I was about to do something intractable, you should have punished me with daily hunger and thirst, and with beatings.

app.lem: λ sy tu asy fezyeras non podiera yo fazer njnguna cosa
app.rdg: If you had done so, I would not have been able to make such mistakes.

app.lem: mas quando te pedia gallynas dauas me tu gallynas λ capones
app.rdg: But when I asked for chicken, instead you gave me chickens and cockerel meat.

app.lem: ¶ Et sy te pedia vyno blanco dauas me tu alfaxor λ buen vyno bermejo ¶ Et fartauas me muy bien
app.rdg: And if I asked you for white wine, you would give me almond pastries, and nice red wine, and you filled me well.

app.lem: ¶ Et despues que era farto sy te pedia muger tu luego mela dauas
app.rdg: And after I was completely stuffed, if I asked you for a woman, you would then give me one.

app.lem: λ non ujeja mas moça λ non de rruta mas vyrgen λ non mas tantas que non auja que fazer
app.rdg: And not an old one, but a maiden, and not deflowered, but a virgin, and much more than you should have done.

app.lem: ¶ Et otrosy que non auja culpa ¶ Et prueuo lo asy por buena rrazon de esperança manjfiesta
app.rdg: Furthermore, there was no shame in it and I will prove it to you with the good reason of manifest destiny.

app.lem: ca bien non puede fazer njnguna cosa que bien vees que el cuerpo con admjnjtelo dela anjma biue λ con su ayuda creçe
app.rdg: For certainly I cannot do anything that you do not see quite well; for the body lives with the permission of the soul and with its help grows.

app.lem: ¶ Et pues el anjma esto faze bien vees que en ella es el poder ¶ Et el querer pues ella es la que deue rregir λ castigar al cuerpo lo qual synon fizo λ non domo luego los deleytes del mundo lo ensandeçe
app.rdg: And the spirit does this well, for you see it is in her where power and desire are found, and she is the one who should govern and warn the body, for if she does not do so, later the temptations of the world will weaken it.

app.lem: λ otrosy bien sabes que la carne es conrronpyble ¶ Et de sy mjsma solamente non sabe nada njn mal njnguno por sy estando non entyende ca todo lo que faze primero sale de ty que eras la que sabes λ entyendes
app.rdg: As you are well aware, the body is susceptible to corruption, and in its purest state knows of nothing bad, but only exists, for everything it first does occurs through you, for you are the one who knows and understands.

app.lem: que yo por mj syn ty non so nada que la carne non sabe nada que es lo que su anjma cobdiçia njn que es lo que aborreçe pues sy el anjma tyene el querer ¶ Et pone las cosas por obra ca las manos λ los otros entramjentos dela carne que es sy sierua que culpa ha la carne que es su sirujenta
app.rdg: For without you I am nothing; the body knows nothing of what the soul covets or that which it loathes, for if it is the soul that has desire, and executes the work of God, what blame can the body, as its subject, assume?

app.lem: çierto la culpa es dela anjma que cobdiçian las cosas λ las entyende λ las pone por obra que non del cuerpo que faze su seruiçio
app.rdg: Clearly, the blame goes to the soul, who desires things and understands them and carries out actions, not to the body that serves the soul.
Now believe me, you are the one who sinned more severely by virtue of following my weak, impure will.
Now that you well see destiny manifest in me, without you, the desires manifested in me could not do anything, they are so weak.
I don’t even have the strength to defend myself from such little things like these maggots that gnaw at my ribs.
Go away from here, I don’t want to talk to you anymore!”
And the soul responded very abruptly, and said: “I still want to stay here and debate with you for I am idle and have time on my hands.

Tell me, you dishonest, traitor of a corpse, why have you embittered me with such harsh words and insults as you have just now said wishing to throw all the blame on me for the acts of treason that you committed?
Tell me now traitor, for I can quite well tell you that while you lived a treacherous lie.
Who showed you how, or where did you learn how to speak in such a brash manner?
Despite the fact that you might have had good reason for some of what you said, your rational is more of a rebuttal to my speech of which I will not respond to.
But I will respond to what you have said about me being responsible for actions, that I should have warned you in advance.

I’ll tell you that you speak the truth about this, but as you well know, when I wanted to advise you to pray or fast, you would then bring me to imagine the flavor of lamb during the hunger that you felt.
It is by virtue of your worldly arrogance that we are now condemned.
Furthermore, when I wanted to beat you or make you abstain from things, you would then entice me with sensual pleasures.
And how much you complained, saying that it was such a harsh thing that I could bring you harm, and that you would get sick, while driving me away from my good thoughts.
And you always followed your desires, and therefore that is why I should chastise you.
In the doctrine that I tried to give you, bad treacherous false corpse, you will always loose against me, you must accept it.
You put the vanities of the world before me until such self-indulgence brought me to hell.
I know that I’m to blame for making the mistake of not maintaining greater control over you and not restraining you, but why did you trick me with such sweet deceit?
You know that in the end you should seriously pity me.

Certainly, if you, wretched and foolish corpse, if you had placed less value on the riches of the world, the temptations of the devil, his pleasantries, if you would have devoted yourself to the service of God, I would have reached heaven and enjoyed the company of the archangels.
But even the other day, the devil laughed with a scowl.
What did he promise you, that you would live a long life and that you would find fulfillment in your material belongings?
Then you did not heed death believing that it was true.
And look at yourself now, how ashamed you should be, for death can come at any moment and tear you away from your palace and the vanity that you lived in.
Now that you rest rotting, now you can ponder what is the real value of your time on earth, for the world takes advantage of naïve, self-indulgent men.
And the men who flatter the man that they wish to fool, they rather show him desire making him an unbeliever.
With their words and false smile, speaking through their teeth as if laughing, the man loves them more than the rest because he puts his trust in them, and then the better they can deceive him.
This is the way the world works.
It is the men that are closest to perdition that receive the greatest honors and riches, and after they have received treats and sweet delicacies, and fragrant smelling food.
Certainly, it is the well-governed body that should live.
And furthermore, the body without the spirit can’t take advantage of anyone, and isn’t anything.
As you are well aware, the soul is indebted to the Lord God, and if it were by his grace, the body would never be able to escape from the service or will of the spirit.
If, in the meantime, you would have lived with a good conscious and loved God truly, and if you had litigated with such trust, you would have given just sentences.
And if you had never attained the customs of bad men, the vanity of the world would never have tricked you and me.
But because I was made to be, at the very least, your companion, and I have remained so until I now occupy this sad, gloomy house with its dank stench of rot with you.
And I know quite well that I am to endure even more suffering and pain until I am resurrected with you on the final Day of Judgment.
Sad, angry, and in pain will I exist from know on with you suffering forever more infinite pain and in desperation for forgiveness.
It kills me that there is no man that can be counted on to go on forever, that never more will be.”
And when the spirit heard this, it began to scream with rancor, “Oh that I were never born!
Oh poor me, why did you, Lord God, make me in your image, for you knew that I would be lost.
Oh, poor me, that I should take on such traits that wild animals have!
From the moment that the spirit leaves the body, at this moment, its body is dead and will never live again.
Prisoner that I am, I now wish that God would end the reign of bad men, for as the spirit leaves the body, it then dies with it and remains dead never more in pain.
And if it pleased God that I would exist in this way, I would rather die and not continue to suffer the pains that suit you and me, as we remain everlasting in hell with the demons.”

Then the body, when it heard the spirit say that it should remain with her in hell, and, furthermore seeing its immense weeping, became filled with fear, and it said, “I’m begging you, spirit, tell what is this hell that you threaten me with?
Have you been there?
Have you seen it or heard about it before?
Tell me if you know if there is any hope for those who are in hell to reach heaven and the sweet presence of Jesus Christ?
Tell me now, what does God remember?
Do you know if he will forgive those men who lived an honorable life, and those who were noblemen, and even conceited, rich men, what of them?
For in the world that we have departed from, they occupied great thrones and richly adorned seats.
Is there any hope for those who have inherited money, or received money from the king, or that were a count or any other kind of rich man?
Tell me now, if you would please ease my heart, for you have given me quite a fright with what you have said and the way you cry.”
The soul then responded saying, “Oh, traitor, treacherous fool, you can’t now understand the things that are Good.
Don’t you see that this question you now ask me is a foolish question?

And it’s little worth explaining, for it is well known that all people of the world that die in mortal sin, whether they be holy ordained priests, or emperors, or kings, or of any other kind of social status, are all in the end condemned to the eternal flames of hell where they will never more have hope of any pardon neither through penitence or prayer.
And I’ll further chastise you by saying that you would not be pardoned with all the devotional prayers to the saints, and all the fasting and abstinence that the religious people of the world do.
Furthermore, any riches that exist in the world are given by the love of God.

All that exists in the world, all that sustains us is made possible by God, almost as if any soul, and not any of those that are demons in hell, would tell you for certain that it’s not something that you could do yourself or seek out.
The reason is that it is the soul that is condemned to hell can no longer seek the grace of God.
I’m certain that the Devil is so bad-tempered and so cruel and without pity, that he wouldn’t give up one single soul for all the riches of the world, such is his contempt for the spirits.
But, as far as your question is concerned, if some of the people of good lineage are pardoned, those who were lords in the world, and governed over other men, to that I will respond.
I’ll tell you for certain that the more honorable the man was in the world, and the wealthier he became through such honor, the father he will fall down in the depths of hell.
Don’t you see that the man that is condemned for committing sin, even the more rich and honorable that he might have been, the more they torment him and the harder the pain they inflict upon him?”
And the soul having made its plea in speaking about these things, would have wanted to say more if she had been given the space to do so.
“Behold! Suddenly, two frightful demons, blacker than tar, and very ugly, even more vile in shape than painters could depict fell upon them.
Their mouths were gaping open, their teeth were disordered and large like a hoe, and through the opening of their noses maggots and many other dirty things didn’t cease to fall.
And very cruel serpents, and snakes like scorpions did not cease to attack and wound the soul.
Their eyes were very large and shined as if they resembled flames; they shined as if lit up with fire.
And they had horns on their foreheads and at the end of them rotten venom did not cease to ooze out.
And they had enormous open ears from which blood with a bad stench seeped out in such a way that it was an abhorrent thing to witness.
For that blood was the blood of the souls that they tore apart with their teeth.
They were covered with blood in their ears and throats and they held in their hands iron spears with sharp tips.
And the nails of their feet were similar to the fangs of a wild boar, except that they were much larger sharpened into a point.
And suddenly they were threw her down toward hell, and there amassed a great host of demons that were ready to welcome them where they were made terrible as the Goths.
And bored with stabbing it with their spears and stakes that carried perforating her with holes, they began to rip open its belly with iron axes and they tormented the body with such cruelty.
Without pity they whipped it and defecated in its mouth and throat and filled it with a smelly poison and they shot it in the mouth, eyes, and ears with infernal lead pellets.
And they bit into with their teeth so aggressively that they had consumed its face in an instance.
And in this way they beat on it with their nails, horns, and teeth so fiercely that suddenly it did not seem that they would have been any more angry than they were with it.
While doing this, they began to speak about whether they were married to those who serve us, where in such service we know how to honor them.
Those who are indebted to that world and do what we advise them to do, the prize that we give them is nothing to look forward to.
Now you have a glimpse of what will happen to you.”
“When the soul heard this, it gave a weak cry as though it were trying to resuscitate the half dead corpse.
And pushing it through the gates of hell, it spoke as best it could in such a way that the man could barely hear it whisper up close.
And it said, "Oh Jesus Christ, son of David, this creature is of those that you made in your likeness."
When the demons heard this, they contested with great howls, "It is too late now to call upon your God, it is of no use now to bed or pray, they aren’t worth anything in hell.
There is no hope here for anything.
There is no hope here; you will never again see the light.
You will remain idle in this darkness, enjoying the pleasure that you see here, we will give you even more consolation and you will honor us.
For now you assume a superficial image that you can no longer trust.
We will transform you as beautiful as we are, and from now on you will always be in our company.
And you will know the favors we do for those who help us.”
I, Filbert, author of this book, being here to recount these things that have happened, awoke with a fright.
I sat a while, as there was no strength left in my body from the shock of seeing this frightful vision.
Remaining terrified of what had happened, I found myself on the floor, where I had fallen asleep.
I raised my hands up toward heaven in prayer to God.
In my prayer, I began to beg fervently for the forgiveness and pity of God that he free me from hell and from such pain that I witnessed the soul suffer.

And from then on, I forgot about all my quotidian cares, and I renounced all the treasures, riches, bequests, and all other material things of this world, for they are not everlasting, and I discarded of them.
And I devoted myself to my Lord Jesus Christ, "may He be eternally praised. Amen."
For the entire world is lost in sin and commits more bad deeds every day.
Furthermore, justice is lost in our sins.
And the lawyers that declare other men to be wise are drenched in their own sins and bad deeds for which reason they should not hold the title of lawyer or wise man.
But the careless idiots, that throughout the world have heard this be said, know that the world is already lost, that there is no other God, only vanity, mockery, and money.

And that man which has a lot of money, and bequests and riches, he who the people adore (and not God), for they do not know who he is, and in this way they separate themselves from God and loose their virtues, hope, and faith.
Goodwill is lost, according to theology those virtues that are marvelous and sacred are now all but drowned out and lost.
For as much grace as a man possesses, he should only mind the virtues, but he gives trickery and greed precedence, and the most vile and dirtiest of bad deeds.
Those that sin only care about how they can accumulate more money, and these are the people who flatter and honor the noblemen.

This is how noblemen are created, even if they are of beautiful countenance, and despite their status good-natured and humble, and well mannered with other good qualities, the moment they become poor, they are vilified and declared worthless and stupid.

And even if I were a bad man with bad manners, and had committed many sins, if by coincidence I was rich and the treasurer of the king, and went about covered in rich honorable garments, and surrounded by squires, then, regardless of my deeds, they would believe that I am a highly intelligent, wise man.
And then, people would come from near and far to admire and embrace the man with a bickering smile, telling him, “do you know, sir, that I am your nephew?” and the other, “I am your cousin.”
Such adoration makes a man arrogant, but when death comes, and he looses all his kin, and their love is lost in, to the extent that they all run away from him right before his death.
Then they forget about him, as if they had never known him, those who once flattered him.
They elevated him when they revered and embraced him, and kissed his hands, mouth, and nose, revering him.
The vanity of the world is a fiendish thing; it’s a horrible poison to the virtues, and clouds the minds of men.

For you have loved the passing things that look and feel more like flames and painful love, and crying bitter tears, you seek the sweet taste of the corruptible and temporary things that men so covet.
For they well understand that you have been poisoned and corrupted, that it is not merely a passing bad habit.
This is how money can turn the clear will of a judge who would have declared the right.
It is by knowingly giving bad sentences that souls are corrupted, who are a spiritual beings.
By living in avarice and greed, men ruin their souls, even though they had no good reason to love money so.
And if they could buy three things with money, they would be: 1) eternal youth without old age, 2) eternal life, and 3) life without death.
If they could achieve this with money, one could rationalize the desire to accumulate it.
But you, you wretched man, didn’t you stop to think about how death takes away all material things?
If not, tell me what has existed for all of eternity since the world was created and which is now alive and never dies?
Certainly, you could not tell me of anyone, except that we are mortal creatures.
And I don’t speak of the miracles that God makes who created Elias’s terrestrial paradise.
Oh that we should never die, but that we die when it pleases God.
That the aforementioned is true, is evidenced in the experience that we have every day of seeing those who were alive yesterday, now rotting underground.
It marvels me how the man who is apprehensive about death cannot experience pleasure in it.
As if he knows that one has to die but does not know where he will go afterward, or that a man has no thought that would later make him cry.
Now I tell you, that I don’t know how long I should remain by your side or leave to serve God?
Furthermore, it’s certain that the time a man spends with the ceiling of his home directly above his face, he cannot be tempted by the vanities of the world.
If he were blinded by mud, he would then not be able to judge anyone, as much clandestine trickery that there is in the world, justice and deceit fall together as one.
There is no law or ordinance that can control the will of man.
Righteous justice and the true law, is the one that our Lord God ordains, which he gives to everyone without exception, as they each merit.

app.lem: Ad am gloria nos perduas ser amen.
app.rdg: No translation in document.
